title: 112_hr2231
content: The "Ethanol Modernization and Deficit Reduction Act" terminates ethanol tax credits by amending the Internal Revenue Code to end excise tax credits and direct payments on June 30, 2011. The income tax credit deadlines are also moved to June 30, 2011, and July 1, 2011. These changes apply to sales, use, or removal after June 30, 2011. Additionally, the Act extends and modifies the alternative fuel vehicle refueling property credit. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code ends ethanol tax credits and direct payments by June 30, 2011. It also modifies the alternative fuel vehicle refueling property credit by specifying eligible fuel types and setting a minimum number of refueling properties to be in service. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code ends ethanol tax credits and direct payments by June 30, 2011. It also modifies the alternative fuel vehicle refueling property credit by specifying eligible fuel types and setting a minimum number of refueling properties to be in service. The amendment allows for dual-use refueling property with specific requirements for fuel composition. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code modifies the alternative fuel vehicle refueling property credit by specifying eligible fuel types and setting a minimum number of refueling properties to be in service. Dual-use refueling property must be certified for specific usage or face recapture of costs within 5 years. The term 'dual-use refueling property' refers to property that serves as both qualified alternative fuel vehicle refueling property and is used to store or dispense fuels not described in subsection (c)(2) or for purposes other than delivering fuel into a motor vehicle's fuel tank. These amendments apply to property placed in service after June 30, 2011. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend the cellulosic biofuel producer credit and special depreciation allowance for cellulosic biofuel plant property through January 1, 2015. Algae is now considered a qualified feedstock for purposes of the cellulosic biofuel producer credit. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include algae as a qualified feedstock for the cellulosic biofuel producer credit. Qualified feedstock now includes lignocellulosic or hemicellulosic matter available on a renewable basis and cultivated algae. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include algae as a qualified feedstock for the cellulosic biofuel producer credit, along with lignocellulosic or hemicellulosic matter. Special rules apply for algae-derived fuel sold for refining into compliant fuel by another party. Algae is now considered a qualified feedstock for bonus depreciation for biofuel plant property, specifically for second generation biofuel production. Amendments have been made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to reflect this change. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include changing references from "cellulosic biofuel" to "second generation biofuel" in various sections. This aligns with the recognition of algae as a qualified feedstock for bonus depreciation in biofuel plant property for second generation biofuel production. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 involve replacing references to "cellulosic biofuel" with "second generation biofuel" in specific sections. The changes apply to fuels sold or used after the enactment date of the Act. The amendments made by subsection (c) apply to property placed in service after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 7. BUDGETARY EFFECTS. The budgetary effects of this Act shall not be entered on any PAYGO scorecard.
